Fringe Review: Jamie MacDowell and Tom Thum

By James Bithell

Take one sexy singer-songwriter, and a top-notch beat-boxer and you get a musical duo that are redefining musical parameters

Fringe Review: Andrew Maxwell - Banana Kingdom

By James Bithell

Ireland's stand-up comedy king, Andrew Maxwell is back again for yet another gig at the Edinburgh fringe. But does the show live up to the hype, asks Jordan Licht

Fringe Review: Snakes Pretending to be Seat Belts

By James Bithell

A cross between the Mighty Boosh, Alice and Wonderland and Jurassic Park, Australian comedy duo Gravity Boots will make you question your sanity

Fringe Review: WitTank Presents The School

They made us chortle with their mini comedy bites on BBC 3. But can they sustain our laughter with a full-blown live comedy sketch show? Jordan Licht thinks they really, really, definitely can

Fringe Review: Contractions

As the Edinburgh fringe is catapulted into full-swing, Jordan Licht is glad to see a university drama show amongst those setting the standard for the festival.

Review: Seasons

By James Bithell

Four strong lead voices go some way to balancing out Season's weak lyrics and lack of the energy that defines the best of the West End. Rosemary Collins reviews.

Review: Mount Holyoke College Art Museum

By James Bithell

One of the oldest collegiate galleries in the world leads Sonali Dutta through an expansive collection.

Review: The Royal Academy Summer Exhibition 2013

You've got one month left to see this astoundingly broad ranging and historically influential exhibition at the heart of London. Katy Gregory reviews.

Review: Paper, Saatchi Gallery, London

By James Bithell

The Saatchi Gallery hosts Paper, which addresses important questions over where art and the rest of the world is heading. Katy reviews.

Review: A Reading by Seamus Heaney

York alumnus Seamus Heaney injects his own rich work on North and South to the Festival of Ideas. Georgia Woodroffe reviews.

Interview: John Wakefield, 'Trimble' producer.

By James Bithell

Rory Foster speaks to John Wakefield about the upcoming live radio sitcom, 'Trimble'.

Review: Hedda Gabler

By James Bithell

The Norwegian classic impresses but fails to fulfill its potential. Sam Hickford reviews.

Campus Arts: Review of the Year

By James Bithell

York's Arts scene has grown every year with societies being born, growing and developing to new heights every year. Our reviewers take a look over the year's best creative endeavours.

Book review: And the Mountains Echoed - Khaled Hosseini

By James Bithell

Hosseini certainly lives up to his name of 'master storyteller' in a novel that explores unspoken feelings and regrets. Heather Stewart reviews.

Review: Pantomime Redemption

By James Bithell

Pantomime Redemption uses all the mighty arsenal of comedy stockpiled by pantomimes to explore the role of that dying art. Sam Hickford reviews.

Review: Little Women, the Musical

A beautiful and uniquely memorable performance of this cracking classic graces York campus. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Norman Rea Summer Exhibition - "The Circle"

By James Bithell

The Norman Rea offers 'The Circle', which makes for a fascinating collection of pieces, some with more obvious links to the theme of circles than others, but all nonetheless thought-provoking. Lauren Spence reviews.

Review: The Mercy Seat

A cloying claustrophobia seeps through the Mercy Seat as a couple face a difficult decision in front of the backdrop of the great American disaster. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Bitch Boxer

By James Bithell

In this exploration of one female boxer's ambition and motivation, the heart behind this ruthless sport stuns us in its iron beauty. Georgia Woodroffe reviews

Review: The Trench

By James Bithell

Despite the stunning visuals and beautiful choreography, Joseph Bevan is disappointed with the narrative of Les Enfants Terribles' latest offering, The Trench.

Review: The Agony and Ecstasy of Steve Jobs

By James Bithell

Although eager to see what this globally acclaimed performer could offer, Thomas Cox is thoroughly disappointed.

Review: After The End

By James Bithell

After The End is the Drama Barn's latest offering; a psychological thriller involving the story of two atomised people forced to its harrowing conclusion. Sam Hickford reviews.

Review: Hay Festival

By James Bithell

Hay Festival delights with punctuation and literary kings. Hennie Thompson reviews.

Review: The Lesson

By James Bithell

Paapa reviews the drama barn's latest offering: Eugene Ionesco's The Lesson.

Review: Words and Whippets

York Theatre Royal hosts an evening of Yorkshire's most prolific Spoken Word Artists. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: Juliet and Romeo

By James Bithell

Romeo meets Juliet, Macbeth, and Hamlet, in a daring improv show. Sam Hickford reviews.

Review: Rutherford and Son

By James Bithell

Gritty, tense and stifling, Rutherford and Son is certainly no feel-good experience. Ruby Cooper reviews.

'Not He, Not I'

By James Bithell

Beckett's play, performed at the 'speed of thought', is a cacophony of voices demanding to be heard

Review: The Misanthrope

By James Bithell

Roger McGough keeps the magic of Moliere alive in his rejuvenation of The Misanthrope. Poppy Bullard reviews

Review: The Knight of the Burning Pestle

By James Bithell

The Knight of the Burning Pestle crafts a good play out of a bad one. Mungo Tatton-Brown reviews.
